pullrequest.title: Clamp window size to fit screen

content.raw: I originally uncovered this because collapsible widgets can end up expanding “down” off the screen \(which if I understood the description correctly isn’t planned to be addressed by this PR\). I’ve noticed that when I’m using some layouts, however, the collapsible widgets expand “up”. Do you know what controls this behaviour? Maybe to address my concern of collapsible widgets expanding off the screen, we can instead force them to expand “up” somehow?

content.raw:
I saw the jump that the collapsible widget was doing when I fist reviewed pull request #137, but I'm not sure why it would expand beyond the window. I think in that case, what we want to do is:

1. Put all widgets inside a `QScrollArea` that takes up the whole plugin space
1. Add a spacer after the very last widget so that it takes up all the free space

Let me know if this clarifies things.

content.raw:
yeah, eventually 137 will have a scrollable area, I’m with you on that. The reason I mention it here is because I’ve also seen this behaviour with just the plain Grid3D widget, so I figured it might be something we can address for all collapsible widget usage instead of just that one use case \(I imagine there will be more in the future\). It’s not really a *major* issue though.

To answer my own question, I think the reason the collapsible expands “up” sometimes is just if it can fit in the window by shrinking other things above it. If it can’t, it expands “down” and forces the window to expand. This implies a sufficient workaround is also to ensure that the widget is used in a place where it will have enough space \(e.g. scrollable as you mentioned\).

pullrequest.title: Clamp window size to fit screen

content.raw:
I tested this on a laptop with an external monitor. I noticed the following:

1. One  time when launching the huge\_window config, it resized it to the builtin laptop display’s size, but it ended up showing it on the external monitor \(where resizing wasn’t necessary\). Is there a way to know the size of the display that will be used?
2. Resizing to exactly the detected resolution doesn’t quite resolve the original issue, because if I have a menubar at the top of my screen, I still can’t access the bottom of the window  to resize the window. Perhaps it is possible to detect the maximum  possible window size in a way that accounts for these menus \(or just add  a buffer, but that’s a bit arbitrary\).
3. It’d be nice but not necessary to also reposition the position of the window if it’s been shrunk. Currently it can be made to fit by dragging it up, but it still starts off the monitor.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/512309280-scene3d_resized.png)
‌
